thread.title: St. Norbert's Freeman returns to gridiron
thread.title_full: St. Norbert's Freeman returns to gridiron

title: St. Norbert's Freeman returns to gridiron
text:
St. Norbert's Freeman returns to gridiron Andrew Pekarek , Press-Gazette Media 9:39 a.m. CDT October 2, 2015 G.B. Southwest alum playing football again after completing college baseball career Buy Photo St. Norbert College senior Matt Freeman gets up after making a catch against Carthage College on Sept. 5. The Green Bay Southwest alum is playing football for the first time since 2010. (Photo: Jim Matthews/Press-Gazette Media) Buy Photo 
St. Norbert College football coach Dan McCarty recalls seeing perfect spiral after perfect spiral being thrown from the end zone to midfield during warm-ups of the Green Knights’ home opener last year. 
McCarty couldn’t figure out why the individual throwing the passes wasn’t in a helmet and shoulder pads. 
“I talked to the athletic director after the game because I was wondering who the heck that ball boy was,” McCarty said. 
Matt Freeman — the sideline worker responsible for throwing the 50-yard darts in warm-ups last year — is suiting up for St. Norbert this season. 
Freeman is playing football for the first time since 2010, his senior season at Green Bay Southwest. 
The 6-foot-3, 215-pounder got the itch to return to the gridiron for one more season after being a standout pitcher on the St. Norbert baseball team. 
“I realized I wasn’t going to be able to get all my credits done in four years, so I would have to take another semester,” said Freeman, who will graduate at the end of the semester with a degree in business administration. 
“I figured if I’m going to take another semester, I might as well make the most out of it and play football while I do it.” 
Freeman formally introduced himself to McCarty last winter to inquire about joining the football team. 
McCarty, who was promoted from defensive coordinator to head coach in November, was happy to give Freeman the opportunity. 
“If he would have been here for four years, he would have been a hell of a quarterback,” said McCarty, whose team hosts Cornell College at 1 p.m. Saturday. “He showed us within two practices what he could do at wide receiver. We’re happy to have him.” 
Freeman earned first-team all-Midwest Conference North Division honors as a pitcher in the spring. 
Whenever he could, Freeman would swing by spring football practices to watch. 
The former Fox River Classic Conference linebacker of the year wasn’t sure what position he would play when August rolled around. He just knew he wasn’t going to take the opportunity to play football again for granted. 
“The first time putting on pads was a little different,” Freeman said. “But I’d say after one practice it just came back to me. It felt normal.” 
Freeman initially was thinking about going to the University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh and playing football after high school. However, he decided to attend UW-Stevens Point as a freshman and play baseball. 
The right-handed pitcher transferred to St. Norbert as a sophomore. He went 13-8 with 135 strikeouts over 189 ⅔ innings pitched in three seasons, which included helping the Green Knights advance to the NCAA Division III Midwest Regional in 2014. 
“With his age and maturity comes a sense of calmness,” McCarty said. “He’s still learning our offense. But he sees the big picture. He doesn’t get frazzled if he has a bad play or a bad practice. I think you get that with maturity.” 
Freeman has played on special teams in addition to making three catches for 45 yards during the football team’s 3-0 start. 
Trailing 31-28 at North Park (Ill.) University on Sept. 12, Freeman caught a 20-yard pass from Jack Becker on a fourth-and-9 in the final minute to help extend a drive. 
“That was a huge play for us to go in then and score the go-ahead touchdown,” McCarty said about the conversion in a 41-31 road victory. “He’s been a tremendous asset. 
“I kind of think of him as a freshman because this is his first season playing college football. You can see each game he’s getting more comfortable out there.” 
Freeman doesn’t think he would have been comfortable on campus this fall had he not decided to play football. 
“When I was thinking about coming back to play football, I talked to my parents about it because they’re definitely a big influence in my life,” Freeman said. “They said, ‘You’re only in college once. If you look back 20 years from now, you’re not going to regret playing football. You’d regret not playing football.’ That’s how I looked at it.” 
apekarek@pressgazettemedia.com and follow him on Twitter @andrewpekarek. 135 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://gbpg.net/1KPDAbQ TOP VIDEOS
